properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: This afternoon and early this evening, conditions will be favourable to the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 45 knots, frequent lightning and hail. ### Large hail can damage vessels and cause injury. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Moist easterly flow associated with a deep Alberta low will continue to stream moisture across the Rocky Mountains and into B.C. today. Most of these regions have already received significant amounts of rain over the past 24 hours, ranging from 15 to 30 mm, with higher amounts over the mountains, locally up to 30-50 mm. As the main band of organized rainfall slides further North, rain will end rapidly this morning across the Cariboo but persist along an axis extending from Williston to Prince George to Blue River. However, the unstable airmass over regions to the south will favour the development of showers and thunderstorms later in the day. Some heavier showers and thunderstorms will have the potential of adding 10-15 mm locally over short periods well into this evening. Higher rainfall amounts are expected over the mountains, especially over the Williston, McGregor, and Cariboo regions where storm totals will reach 40 to 60 mm.- Although the rainfall amounts may not be exceptionally heavy, the significance of this event is due to the potential for rising rivers levels. There is significant concern for high flows in the Quesnel River (Cariboo Mountains), the North Thompson (Blue River/Clearwater region), and South Thompson (Shuswap). ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-02T21:31:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-02T12:04:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3399727826.2020
Area: South Thompson, Nicola, Shuswap, North Thompson, North Columbia, Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Cariboo - south including Williams Lake, 100 Mile, Yellowhead, Williston, Prince George, McGregor
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: With an approaching upper disturbance and recent heat and moisture in the watch area, conditions are allowing for the development of severe thunderstorms this afternoon in central SK and MB. Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 35 knots. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for isolated severe thunderstorms late this afternoon and this evening. Isolated thunderstorms are expected to move southeastward across the regions late this afternoon and this evening. Locally damaging winds gusts may be associated with one or two of these storms, along with hail and frequent cloud to ground lightning. As the storms are expected to be isolated, many places will not be affected. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-07-03T09:02:06-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms this afternoon. Primary threats from these thunderstorms include wind gusts up to 100 km/h and hail size up to quarter size. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions will be favourable for the development of funnel clouds today. ### These types of funnel clouds are generated by weak rotation under rapidly growing clouds or weak thunderstorms. This weak rotation is normally not a danger near the ground. However, there is a chance that this rotation could intensify and become a weak landspout tornado. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-03T01:59:26-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat event continues today. Daytime high temperatures near 30 degrees Celsius are expected today, with humidex values near 36. Cooler air will move into the region tonight. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the air quality health index to approach the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-03T01:02:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-02T09:03:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1486393126.2020

properties.Title: Canceled: Flood Warning Issued For Southwestern, Western And Central Regions In Manitoba.
properties.Summary:
Description: Cancelled: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure‚Äôs Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a Flood Warning for southwestern, western and central regions of Manitoba. A weather system may release 80 to 150 millimetres of rain in these areas in between June 29 to July 1. Areas in southwest Manitoba, including Virden and Brandon could see up to 175 millimetres of rain during this time. If you are in the affected area, please continue to be watchful as local waterways are expected to rise quickly and may cause flooding. There is a potential for overland flooding in low lying areas. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Use caution when driving on all roads as road conditions may have changed. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by local authorities, listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Stay tuned to local media for updates.
Expires: 2020-07-02T13:00:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-07-02T12:15:00-05:00, 180C1E41-2491-E1C9-5848-B3CBD8BD960A
Area: Southwestern, Western and Central Manitoba
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that are likely to produce very strong wind gusts, damaging hail and heavy downpours this afternoon and early this evening. Boaters could be surprised by strong gusts over smaller bodies of water. ### Very large hail can damage property, break windows, dent vehicles and cause serious injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-03T07:30:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-02T15:31:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0538170409.2020

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of rain, at times heavy, is expected. A further 20 to 30 mm of rain is expected to fall through this afternoon over the Peace River and Fort Nelson regions. The heavy rain is being caused by low pressure centre over central Alberta drifting northwards today. Strong and moist easterly flow associated with the low is generating enhanced precipitation as the flow encounters the eastern slopes of the Rockies. Over the Muncho Lake Park-Stone Mountain Park region the most significant rainfall will be in the Tetsa River region. The low will weaken somewhat and stall near the AB-BC border this afternoon. The character of the precipitation will become more showery with widespread thunderstorms developing this afternoon over northeastern BC that will persist throughout the evening and into the overnight period. These storms will cause local downpours that will contribute to storm rainfall totals. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-03T01:52:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-02T09:53:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0514824314.2020
Area: B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River, Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. With an approaching upper disturbance and recent heat and moisture in the watch area, conditions are allowing for the development of severe thunderstorms this afternoon in central SK and MB. This watch area will likely be extended as the situation develops this afternoon and into this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Locally heavy rain is also possible. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 34 are expected for the next 2 days. A hot and humid airmass has returned to much of southern and east central Manitoba today and will persist into the weekend. Slightly cooler temperatures are expected late in the weekend and into early next week. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. For more information on heat and your health: - Visit Manitoba Health at: http://www.manitoba.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/heat.html. - Call Health Links ‚Äì Info Sant√© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of rain, at times heavy, is expected. A further 20 to 30 mm of rain is expected to fall through this afternoon over the Peace River and Fort Nelson regions. The heavy rain is being caused by low pressure centre over central Alberta drifting northwards today. Strong and moist easterly flow associated with the low is generating enhanced precipitation as the flow encounters the eastern slopes of the Rockies. Over the Muncho Lake Park-Stone Mountain Park region the most significant rainfall will be in the Tetsa River region. The low will weaken somewhat and stall near the AB-BC border this afternoon. The character of the precipitation will become more showery with widespread thunderstorms developing this afternoon over northeastern BC that will persist throughout the evening and into the overnight period. These storms will cause local downpours that will contribute to storm rainfall totals. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-03T01:52:53-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather is expected. Timing: This afternoon through Sunday. The heat event is likely to persist into next week. Maximum temperatures today: 32 to 34 degrees Celsius (Humidex 37 to 39). Maximum temperatures Friday: 32 to 34 degrees Celsius (Humidex 39 to 41). Maximum temperatures Saturday: 32 to 34 degrees Celsius (Humidex 39 to 41). Maximum temperatures Sunday: 33 to 36 degrees Celsius (Humidex 39 to 42). Minimum overnight temperatures: 21 to 23 degrees Celsius. Locations: Extreme Southwestern Ontario including Windsor and Chatham-Kent. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index to approach the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

Thunderstorms are expected to develop this afternoon and persist into this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. With an approaching upper disturbance and recent heat and moisture in the watch area, conditions are allowing for the development of severe thunderstorms this afternoon in central SK and MB. This watch area will likely be extended as the situation develops this afternoon and into this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Locally heavy rain is also possible. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-03T00:49:41-00:00
